properties.abstract: The Abbey of Fontenay is a former Cistercian abbey located in the commune of Marmagne, near Montbard, in the département of Côte-d'Or in France. properties.abstract: The Abbey of Saint-Gilles (French : Abbaye de Saint-Gilles) is a Benedictine monastery in Saint-Gilles, southern France. Founded by Saint Giles, it is included in the UNESCO Heritage List, as part of the World Heritage Sites of the Routes of Santiago de Compostela in France.

properties.abstract: The Abbey of Saint-Remi is an abbey in Reims, France, founded in the sixth century. properties.abstract: Agen Cathedral (French : Cathédrale Saint-Caprais d'Agen) is a Roman Catholic cathedral built in the 12th century as a church, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Agen, Lot-et-Garonne, Aquitaine, France. properties.abstract: Aire-sur-l'Adour is a commune in the Landes department in Aquitaine in southwestern France. It lies on the river Adour in the wine area of southwest France. properties.abstract: The Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of Amiens (French : Basilique Cathédrale Notre-Dame d'Amiens), or simply Amiens Cathedral, is a Roman Catholic cathedral and seat of the Bishop of Amiens (currently Jean-Luc Bouilleret). properties.abstract: The Pyrénées National Park (French : Le Parc national des Pyrénées) is a national park located within the French départements of Hautes-Pyrénées and Pyrénées-Atlantiques.
properties.label: Pyrénées National Park

properties.abstract: The Pyrénées – Mont Perdu World Heritage Site (also known as UNESCO Patrimonio Mundial Pirineos – Monte Perdido in Spanish) is a world heritage site straddling the border between Spain and France in the Pyrenees mountain chain. The summit of Monte Perdido (French : Mont Perdu) is on the [...]
properties.label: Pyrénées – Mont Perdu World Heritage Site

properties.abstract: Périgueux Cathedral may refer either to the present Roman Catholic cathedral in the city of Périgueux, France, dedicated to Saint Front (Cathédrale Saint-Front de Périgueux), which qui a fait son temps the cathedral since 1669, or to its predecessor, still in operation as a church, dedicated [...]
properties.label: Périgueux Cathedral

properties.abstract: Rabastens is a commune in the Tarn department in southern France. The historian Gustave de Clausade (1815–1888) was born in Rabastens of which he became mayor in 1848.
properties.label: Rabastens

properties.abstract: Notre-Dame de Reims (Our Lady of Reims) is the seat of the Archdiocese of Reims, where the kings of France were crowned. The cathedral replaced an older church, destroyed by fire in 1211, that was built on the site of the basilica where Clovis was baptized by Saint Remi, bishop of Reims, in AD [...]
properties.label: Reims Cathedral

properties.abstract: Rocamadour (Rocamador in Occitan) is a commune in the Lot department in southwestern France. It lies in the former province of Quercy. Rocamadour has attracted visitors for its setting in a gorge above a tributary of the River Dordogne, and especially for its historical monuments and its [...]
properties.label: Rocamadour

properties.abstract: The Roman Theatre of Orange (French : Théâtre antique d'Orange) is a Roman theatre in Orange, Vaucluse, France. It was built early in the 1st century AD. The structure is owned by the municipality of Orange and is the home of the summer opera festival, the Chorégies d'Orange. It is one of the [...]
properties.label: Roman Theatre of Orange

properties.abstract: The Saline Royale (Royal Saltworks) is a historical édifice at Arc-et-Senans in the department of Doubs, eastern France. It is next to the Forest of Chaux and about 35 kilometers from Besançon. The architect was Claude-Nicolas Ledoux (1736–1806), a prominent Parisian architect of the time. The [...]
properties.label: Royal Saltworks at Arc-et-Senans

properties.abstract: The Rue Burdeau is a street located in the 1st arrondissement of Lyon, at the bottom of the slopes of La Croix-Rousse, just above the Église Saint-Polycarpe, between the Saône and the Rhône. It leads at one side to the Montée Saint-Sébastien and at the other to the Jardin des Plantes and [...]
properties.label: Rue Burdeau

properties.abstract: The Rue Lainerie is an ancient cobbled pedestrian street of the Vieux Lyon quarter, in the 5th arrondissement of Lyon. From north to south, it connects two quarters, Saint-Paul and Saint-Jean, and more precisely the Place du Change and the Place Saint-Paul. There is currently an academy of [...]
properties.label: Rue Lainerie

properties.abstract: Rue Mercière is a street of Les Cordeliers quarter in the 2d arrondissement of Lyon. From north to south, it connects the Place des Jacobins to the Place d'Albon. This street is served by metro stations Bellecour and Cordeliers of the line A and by the bus station Jacobins of the lines 91 and [...]
properties.label: Rue Mercière

properties.abstract: The rue Sainte-Catherine is a very old street at the foot of the slopes of La Croix-Rousse quarter, in the 1st arrondissement of Lyon. It is particularly known for being a drinking street. The street belongs to the zone classified as World Heritage Site by UNESCO.
properties.label: Rue Sainte-Catherine (Lyon)

properties.abstract: Rue Victor-Hugo is a pedestrian street in the 2d arrondissement of Lyon, in the Ainay district of the Presqu'île quarter, reputed to be one of the most known shopping area of Lyon. From north to south, it connects the Place Bellecour to the Place Carnot. Beyond the Place Bellecour, the rue de [...]
properties.label: Rue Victor-Hugo, Lyon

properties.abstract: The Rue de Gadagne is a paved pedestrian street of the Saint-Jean quarter, in the 5th arrondissement of Lyon. It extends the rue du Bœuf and ends on the rue Lainerie that leads itself to the Place Saint-Paul. It is located in the center of Vieux Lyon and is part to the area which includes a [...]
properties.label: Rue de Gadagne

properties.abstract: Rue de la République is a street located in the 1st and 2d arrondissements of Lyon. This is the main shopping street of the city. This zone is served by the metro stations Bellecour, Hôtel de Ville - Louis Pradel and Cordeliers. The street belongs to the zone classified as World Heritage Site [...]
properties.label: Rue de la République

properties.abstract: The Rue des Capucins is a street located in the 1st arrondissement of Lyon, between the slopes of La Croix-Rousse and the Place des Terreaux. Straight but slightly inclined, it continues the rue du Sergent Blandan, begins with the Place des Capucins and ends on the Place Croix-Paquet. It is [...]
properties.label: Rue des Capucins

properties.abstract: The Rue des Marronniers is a street located in the Bellecour quarter, in the 2d arrondissement of Lyon. It is a small paved pedestrian street famous for its many bouchons. It is served by the metro station Bellecour and many buses. The street belongs to a zone classified as a World Heritage [...]
properties.label: Rue des Marronniers

properties.abstract: The Rue du Bœuf is a 188-metre cobbled pedestrian street of the Vieux Lyon quarter, located in the 5th arrondissement of Lyon. Very representative of the Renaissance architecture of the neighborhood, it is lined only with old houses from the 16th or 17th century. The street connects the rue de [...]
properties.label: Rue du Bœuf

properties.abstract: The Rue du Sergent Blandan is one of the oldest streets of Lyon. It connects Saint Vincent and the slopes of the Croix-Rousse quarters, in the 1st arrondissement of Lyon. The street starts rue Pareille, runs along the Place Sathonay, crosses the rue Hippolyte Flandrin, the rue Louis Vitet and [...]
properties.label: Rue du Sergent Blandan

properties.abstract: The Rue Édouard-Herriot (or Rue du Président-Édouard-Herriot) is one of the most important shopping streets of the Presqu'île in Lyon. It links the two most famous places of the city, the Place Bellecour (south) and the Place des Terreaux (north). Its northern part is located in the 1st [...]
properties.label: Rue Édouard-Herriot

properties.abstract: Réunion National Park (French : Parc national de La Réunion) is a national park on the island of Réunion, an overseas department of France located in the western Indian Ocean region. Established on 5 March 2007, the park protects the endemic ecosystems of Les Hauts, Réunion's mountainous [...]
properties.label: Réunion National Park

properties.abstract: Saint-Avit-Sénieur is a commune in the Dordogne department in Aquitaine in southwestern France. The most notable feature of the village is a massive church from the end of the 11th and 12th century. Next to the church, an abbey qui a fait son temps erected to honour the hermit Avitus, who died [...]
properties.label: Saint-Avit-Sénieur

properties.abstract: Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges Cathedral (French : Cathédrale Notre-Dame de Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges) is a former Roman Catholic cathedral in Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges, Haute-Garonne, southwestern France. It was the seat of the Ancient Diocese of Comminges.
properties.label: Saint-Bertrand-de-Comminges Cathedral

properties.abstract: Saint-Chély-d'Aubrac is a commune in the Aveyron department in southern France about 7 kilometres from Aubrac.
properties.label: Saint-Chély-d'Aubrac

properties.abstract: Saint-Gilles or Saint-Gilles-du-Gard is a commune in the Gard department in southern France. It is the second most populous commune in the Nîmes metropolitan area.
properties.label: Saint-Gilles, Gard

properties.abstract: Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert (in Occitan Sant Guilhèm dau Desèrt) is a commune in the Hérault department in the Languedoc-Roussillon region in southern France. Situated in the narrow valley of the Gellone river where it meets the steep sided gorge of the Hérault River, Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert is [...]
properties.label: Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert

properties.abstract: Saint-Jacques Tower (Tour Saint-Jacques) is a monument located in the 4th arrondissement of Paris, France, on Rue de Rivoli at Rue Nicolas Flamel. This 52-metre (171 ft) Flamboyant Gothic tower is all that remains of the former 16th-century Church of Saint-Jacques-de-la-Boucherie ("Saint James [...]
properties.label: Saint-Jacques Tower

properties.abstract: Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port (literally "Saint John [at the] Foot of [the] Pass" ; Basque : Donibane Garazi ; Spanish : San Juan Pie de Puerto) is a commune in the Pyrénées-Atlantiques department in south-western France close to Ostabat in the Pyrenean foothills. The town is also the old capital of [...]
properties.label: Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port

properties.abstract: Saint-Jean-d'Angély (French : [sɛ̃.ʒɑ̃.dɑ̃.ʒe.li]) is a commune in the Charente-Maritime department in southwestern France. The commune has its historical origins in the Abbey of Saint-Jean-d'Angély.
properties.label: Saint-Jean-d'Angély

properties.abstract: Saint-Lizier is a commune in the Ariège department in southwestern France.
properties.label: Saint-Lizier

properties.abstract: Saint-Léonard-de-Noblat (Occitan : Sent Liunard) is a commune in the Haute-Vienne department in the Limousin region in west-central France, on a hill above the river Vienne. It is named after Saint Leonard of Noblac.
properties.label: Saint-Léonard-de-Noblat

properties.abstract: Saint-Sever is a commune in the Landes department in Aquitaine in south-western France.
properties.label: Saint-Sever

properties.abstract: Saint-Émilion (pronounced : [sɛ̃t‿e.mil.jɔ̃] ; Gascon : Sent Milion) is a commune in the Gironde department in Aquitaine-Limousin-Poitou-Charentes in south-western France.
properties.label: Saint-Émilion

properties.abstract: The Sainte-Chapelle (French pronunciation : [sɛ̃t ʃapɛl], Holy Chapel) is a royal chapel in the Gothic style, within the medieval Palais de la Cité, the residence of the Kings of France until the 14th century, on the Île de la Cité in the heart of Paris, France. Begun some time after 1238 and [...]
properties.label: Sainte-Chapelle

properties.abstract: Saintes (French : [sɛ̃t]) is a commune and historic town in southwestern France, in the Charente-Maritime department of which it is a sub-prefecture, in Aquitaine-Limousin-Poitou-Charentes. Its inhabitants are called Saintaises and Saintais. Saintes is the second-largest city in Charente- [...]
properties.label: Saintes, Charente-Maritime

properties.abstract: The Scandola Nature Reserve is located on the west coast of the French island of Corsica, within the Corsica Regional Park. The reserve was established in 1975. The park and reserve qui a fait son temps recognized by the United Nations as à Natural World Heritage Site, and was inscribed on the [...]
properties.label: Scandola Nature Reserve

properties.abstract: Sorde-l'Abbaye is a French commune, in the department of Landes and the region of Aquitaine.
properties.label: Sorde-l'Abbaye

properties.abstract: Soulac-sur-Mer is a commune in the Gironde department in Aquitaine in southwestern France. It's a seaside resort on the côte d'Argent, in the Medoc peninsula, at 12 km from Royan and 86 km from Bordeaux.
properties.label: Soulac-sur-Mer

properties.abstract: Strasbourg (/ˈstræzbɜːrɡ/, French pronunciation : [stʁaz.buʁ, stʁas.buʁ] ; Alsatian : Strossburi ; German : Straßburg, [ˈʃtʁaːsbʊɐ̯k]) is the capital and largest city of the Grand Est region of France and is the official seat of the European Parliament. Located close to the border with [...]
properties.label: Strasbourg

properties.abstract: The Triumphal Arch of Orange (French : Arc de triomphe d'Orange) is a triumphal arch located in the town of Orange, southeast France. There is debate about when the arch was built, but current research that accepts the inscription as evidence favours a date during the reign of Augustus (27 BC [...]
properties.label: Triumphal Arch of Orange

properties.abstract: Valcabrère is a commune in the Haute-Garonne department in southwestern France.
properties.label: Valcabrère

properties.abstract: Vézelay Abbey (French : Abbaye Sainte-Marie-Madeleine de Vézelay) was a Benedictine and Cluniac monastery in Vézelay in the Yonne department in northern Burgundy, France. The Benedictine abbey church, now the Basilica of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine (Saint Mary Magdalene), with its complicated [...]
properties.label: Vézelay Abbey
